Fields.DialogueText: That was a long haul in the radio room, Captain. Do we have new orders, or is it finally time we make for Midway?
We are... awaiting new arrivals.
Captain? What's going on?
... Okay. An American task force has been redirected from Guam, and there's a rear admiral attached who strongly disagrees with my decision to follow the Morganas here.
We are to escort him back to San Diego, at which point it's possible that I will be relieved of command.
What? Why would you say that?
Because that's what I was told. Nobody's going to strip me of my rank or try to take the rest of the fleet out from under me - but they don't want me to be a bad influence on you.
Oh, hell, no.
It's not settled yet. Don't--
Oh. Hell. No.

Fields.MenuText: Agreed.
Thank you.
We're going to need to meet the admiral and formulate a plan.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. We'll figure this out, Captain. I'm not about to let some idiot with control issues--
Good grief! If these idiots start thinking Belles can't be trusted to choose our captains, this war's going to get even harder than it has to be.
Let's dial back the idiot talk, Pensacola. It *is* fair to say I interpreted our orders... creatively.
You responded to the situation in the field when it was impossible to report home. And that "Captain of the Fleet" rule is supposed to give you latitude to respond on the fly anyway. Isn't it?
Yeah. But there's nothing there that says that ships can't be reassigned out from under me. There's an appeal process, but--
Hang on.
Morganas?
Yeah. I'll come back to talking about how I can restrain you when this is done.
@BATTLE
Nope. I don't want to talk about appeal processes. You're not taking one step off my deck without my permission, and that's final.
Is that an order? Because, technically, you can't give me those.
No, but I can warn you that I can grab you and physically--
I'll be blunt, Captain. I have nothing against you personally - in fact, smarter people than me seem to agree that you're a hero, full stop, and I haven't heard a thing that says they're wrong.

Fields.MenuText: But?
We both know it's not just about the captain. It's the crews I've had the honor of serving with.
I appreciate that, Admiral.

Fields.DialogueText: This isn't my first war, Captain. Even the best crews can be let down by their leadership - and that, at least tactically, hasn't been the case with you.
But we're running this war all wrong, and your example isn't helping.
The ship's Belle is being... irrepressible. I take it you're not happy with confronting Morganas in Japanese-controlled waters? The US made it very clear that Neutrality Fleet participation isn't--
Brace yourself. I've written hundreds of pages on the subject.
Captain, we're fighting a decentralized enemy that seems to subsist primarily on captured materiel to keep themselves going. And they can't go on land!
What we need to do is secure the coastlines - an impenetrable defense. Move all our high-value targets inland. Then just build up bomber capacity.
I've seen your reports - you've documented on a number of occasions just how effective air strikes can be against these things.
And that's it. We cut them off from resources, hit them from on high, and starve them out. Fought defensively, the war can be won in six months.
Instead, what you're doing is taking our naval resources away from defense and launching random sorties against disorganized forces of no strategic value.
Respectfully, Admiral, I think the people of Majuro would disagree. And if the Marshalls became a serious Morgana staging ground, Hawai'i would have some problems as well.
And, frankly, I think naval intelligence is behind the curve on the Morganas' technological capabilities. We've seen evidence of underwater mining and drilling, of--
I'm sorry to interrupt, Captain. Admiral. But I'm hearing an incoming Morgana group.
Admiral, if I can borrow the Captain long enough to sink these things, you should be able to resume explaining why we shouldn't bother by dinnertime.
Listen here, young lady--
Pensacola, prepare for battle. Admiral, this isn't the time for that kind of conversation. It's an honor to have you aboard, but right now I suggest you either head to the bridge or to your quarters.
Understood, Captain. Miss. Good luck.
I know. I meant to.
Let's start by sinking the enemy.
@BATTLE
I appreciate the tour, Captain. I've been on board before, but she's a hell of a sight in wartime. And I respect the crew's professionalism - whatever my problems with you, you run a tight ship.
Thank you, Admiral. If you ever want to talk about those problems...
Informally, you mean? All right.
Hm. You have a strategy incompatible with a string of flawless victories, Admiral?
Hang on.
Pensacola, I'm going to need you to be a good 70% less confrontational here.
I'm going to fight to keep you, Captain. With your permission. I just... need to figure out how to do it right.
That's just the tip of the iceberg, Captain!
... Go on.
Captain? Ma'am? When you have a minute, I have something for you all to look at.
That's... a lot to read, Lieutenant.
I thought you'd been unsettlingly quiet over the last couple of days. Just tell us where we need to sign.
Ma'am, you know how you've told me to tell you when your disdain for paperwork is leading you to make bad choices?
You told her that?
It really doesn't sound like me at all.
*sigh*
This document is a timeline of everything we did since we last left San Diego.
*With* a complete catalog of every major decision the Captain made along with reference to the regulations and precedents that justify them. This right here the first draft of our case.
I haven't slept in thirty-three hours. You're welcome.

Fields.MenuText: Impressive.
I don't actually think we'll need it.
I hate to say it, but I've already written up my own.

Fields.DialogueText: You're damn right, Captain.
Better to have it and not need it than--
I'm joking, Lieutenant. Thank you for going to the trouble.
Oh, thank God.
But I'm sure you found things I didn't. Between the two of us, I'm sure we've worked wonders.
You're impressive as hell, you know that?
Thank you for this, Lieutenant. I applaud your initiative, and - for the record - I don't care about whatever other duties you may have neglected to get this done. Just this once.
The Captain is very well aware.
I'm not sure I'd go that far.
@BATTLE
Captain, do you have time to review this with me? We should probably both have input, and--
I'm guessing I don't have time.
... Nuts.
Frustrating, but true.
Hey. You're already in my quarters.
I let myself in. I hope you don't mind.
The alternative was joining you in arguing with the admiral on the deck, and I think we both know the odds of escalation would've been pretty high.
When you say "escalation," I assume you mean--
I'm not saying I would throw him into the drink, and I'm not saying I wouldn't. My unpredictability is a strength.

Fields.MenuText: Agreed.
One of the many things I like about you.
Aw, you're not *that* unpredictable.

Fields.DialogueText: Good.
Good?
Stop grinning at me and tell me how it went with the admiral.
Uh-huh. I bet you say that to all the cruisers.
You want me to start talking about the stunning design of your barbettes? Because I will.
Pff!
Oh, yeah?
You're always going to do the right thing. You're always going to be stylish about it. And nine times out of ten you'll throw in a football metaphor at the end to make Lieutenant Justice twitchy.
... Okay. That's fair.
Now stop grinning at me and tell me how it went with the admiral.
It was an interesting conversation, if not a really productive one.
I think he genuinely hates the idea of risking you - or presumably any American ship - on missions that aren't vital to American security. And he figures that's at least 50% of what *I* do.
But it's not.
But it's not like I can fault him for... you're getting that look again.
*sigh* Yeah. Yeah, they're maybe thirty miles out and heading our way.
Meet you on the bridge?
I would certainly hope so.
@BATTLE
The man's been on a fact-finding tour in the Pacific for weeks now. He hasn't seen as much of the Morganas as we have, but he's seen enough to take them seriously.
He wants American ships protecting American waters, and that's all. I have a global mandate, and he disagrees with it - so he wants to get you away from me and under a more conservative command.
The fact that I took you off your designated patrol route might give him a political opening.
We're not that far out from San Diego, you know.
Yeah?
And, listen, I would be much more comfortable with the Admiral Kingscote situation if there was something practical I could be doing.
Much as I like watching the crew overhaul filtration systems, it doesn't really feel like it's getting us any closer to not having you transferred onto some sleek French destroyer.

Fields.MenuText: I appreciate that. But the last thing we want to do is overreact.
That's... an unusually specific concern.
Well, I've been thinking about the situation...

Fields.DialogueText: Just wanted to make sure you were paying attention.
The last thing? Really? You're not overreacting right.
Talk me through it.
Okay, first, we need to talk about our opponent here.
Kingscote?
And our response? Based on the last few days, I don't see us changing his mind.
Yeah, changing his mind isn't the objective. It's minimizing the impact of his arguments until we've built up enough good will in US waters for the whole mess to blow over.
So the plan is to do what we normally do and assume it's going to work out?
You disagree?
I don't know. Maybe? I want us to argue our case! I want to be able to say on the record that you're a fantastic captain and you're making my country safer.
... I appreciate that.
Well... you're welcome. By the way, we have Morganas approaching.
*sigh*
Of course we do.
@BATTLE
Seconded!
Pensacola. Lieutenant. Taking a few minutes to breathe?
Seemed like a good time to do it. It's the first night off I've had in ages. Pensacola here doesn't drink--
Some habits a Belle just should not let herself get into.
But you're welcome to have a glass of something that purports to be Pinot noir if your schedule permits.

Fields.MenuText: I don't need booze. I need caffeine.
Don't mind if I do. Thanks.
You want water or something, Pensacola?

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah, I've been there.
You're very welcome!
Aw, thanks. But I know where to find it.
You've met Jerry here - right, Captain?
We haven't really socialized, ma'am. Captain. Um... hello.
Good to see you, Ensign. I've actually been meaning to track you down for a while - I keep seeing you listed as on some kind of "special duty."
He's my "exotic projects" guy, Captain. While the Lieutenant is my all-purpose gopher--
I think the phrase you're looking for is "executive assistant," ma'am.
Jerry here is who I ask to look into strange patterns and whatnot.
Code-breaking?
Sort of? Honestly, it's not that exciting, Captain - it's just that, if you remember when that Despair recording was playing over and over a couple of weeks back...?
I remember.
Well, I just got to wondering if there might be, like, a second message under the first one?
Y'know, if the enemy was distracting us by playing something we would want to *not* pay attention to while tapping out Morse code or something in the background?
... Pensacola. I'm just hearing about this now?
I promise, you'd've heard sooner if there was anything to report.

Yeah. I mean, yes, Captain. It's been a bust. I've recorded dozens of hours of that stuff, and I've tried to graph, like, patterns in the static. So far I'd call it inconclusive. Or maybe just a bust.
Hm. Even so, I'd like you to talk to the Yeoman and see if you two can write up your procedures. It could be worth-
Thought experiments later, Captain.
Morganas?
Coming fast.
Nuts!
@BATTLE
Hello there, Captain!
I hate seeing San Diego dark.
They've got it blacked out for a reason.
I'm not saying it's a bad idea. Just demoralizing.

Fields.MenuText: You okay?
Stay focused, Pensacola. We're not alone out here.
They can turn the lights back on after we sink all the Morganas.

Fields.DialogueText: You and I keep having crises where my job is to keep quiet and let you do your thing. It's not fun.
Don't worry - I haven't forgotten.
Unlikely, but a nice thought.
When it's safe to dock, Kingscote will be leaving us, I assume.
I assume so, too.
Nobody's just going to order you to leave with him, right?
No. I'll be called to some kind of meeting in the next couple of days, and we'll figure things out from there.
Wait. Over there.
I see `em.
@BATTLE
... Listen, I have to say, I appreciate your support here. I know we haven't known each other all that long, but--
It's not always about time, Captain.
No. It's not. Sometimes connections just... happen.
Pensacola, I--
Oh, son of a--
Captain? What's up?
If you can clear an hour from your schedule, I want you to walk me through your... tome here.
Your defense?
For want of a better word, yeah.
I'm happy to help, Captain, but... well, permission to speak as a former debate squad captain?
Granted. With mild amusement.
You already know the subject matter, and you're not going to do yourself any good if you're not relaxed and fresh when it's your turn to talk. You've been going at this really hard for days now.

Fields.MenuText: It's actually a nice change from worrying about Morganas.
Nothing wrong with being thorough, Lieutenant.
Actually, I've been goofing off a good 90% of the time you haven't been around.

Fields.DialogueText: ... That actually sounds a lot like my debate squad career.
Well, no. That's true.
Okay. Fair enough.
*sigh*
Realistically, I'm probably taking this too seriously. This wouldn't be the first time an admiral has tried to get a ship removed from Neutrality Fleet operations, and it's obviously never worked.
But I like it here. She's a good ship and she's got a great crew, and we're doing excellent work. I'm... I don't like the idea of being kicked off.
If it helps, I think there's a pretty good chance that Pensacola would just grab you and run if anybody tried to make you leave.

Fields.MenuText: That actually does make me feel a little better, yeah.
I'd rather it didn't come to that.
She wouldn't have to grab me. I'd already be on the bridge.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, for what it's worth, I--
*ALARM*
Well. I guess we've found a way to take my mind off *that* problem.
@BATTLE
How did the hearing go, Captain? Is this mess over with?
I don't know how it went. It was less formal than I expected, and I wasn't really grilled.
Which sounds good.
I don't know. I wasn't challenged - I wasn't really asked to defend our choices. It's like our record was a secondary factor in whatever decision they're trying to make.
Maybe I should start writing a hundred letters a day to the president.
You might want to start with one and see if it gets past his secretary.
... Captain?
Morganas?
Yeah.
I'll see you on the bridge.
@BATTLE
I wish you could have been there.

Fields.MenuText: I could've used the moral support.
Having informed feedback right now would be handy.
Like, just standing behind me, cracking your knuckles.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, that would've been fun. But...
I honestly don't think they would've invited me even if I could leave the ship.
Outside of Constitution, I'm not sure anybody in America actually wants to think of Belles as people. And, definitely, nobody's asking our opinion about policy.
They let you pick your captains.
You were literally *just* saying you wished I could've been there for the hearing about having my captain taken away from me.
... Fair point.
Where's the fun in...
Captain? It's an honor to meet you.
Commander Keller? Good to meet you, too. I believe my ship's Belle should be around here somewhere too...
Nobody's ordering you to step away from Pensacola - yet - but I've been instructed to ask what it would take to get you to do it voluntarily.
Hello, sailors.
I hope you don't mind the company. She has as much right to know what's going on as anyone.
Plus, we're old friends.
You are?
I didn't think you'd remember me, ma'am. You... weren't awake when I was on board.
This was back in my decadent East Coast days, Captain.
I don't remember much, to be honest. But I know my crew.
Even the dumb kids fresh out of Annapolis with too damn much to prove?
Definitely sounds familiar.
This was back in `32, Captain. I was only aboard for a few months, then I got myself reassigned to be closer to my family, and--
Kid sister, right? Your father had just passed away?
Yes, ma'am. It... it really is you, isn't it?
In the steel.

Fields.MenuText: I hate to interrupt the reunion, but... you had a message for me, Commander?
Should I go for a walk for a few minutes? Give you two a chance to catch up?
A friend of my ship is a friend of mine, Commander. What can I do for you?

Fields.DialogueText: That's nice of you - but I don't think we have any horrible secrets we need to keep.
I do. Um... off the record.
It's... kind of awkward, actually. I won't sugarcoat it.
And you're the one I'm here to talk to, Captain. Off the record.
Nope.
Ma'am...
So, what, your boss wants an end run? Guilting my captain into leaving because the admiralty won't pull the trigger themselves?
Davey, if you weren't one of my boys I would pick you up and throw you into the Pacific.
But, ma'am, there's... I mean, it's not like....
Nope.
But...
Stop.
I mean, I have orders.
Let's simplify things. Captain, what would it take to make you leave me voluntarily?
It's not going to happen, Commander.
... Understood, Captain.
Now, you go back, you report that to whoever sent you out, and you start looking for a posting with somebody who isn't going to waste your valuable time with something as stupid as this. Good grief.
I'll... think about it, ma'am.
And shine your shoes.
Yes, ma'am.
Ma'am?
Hell. Commander, get moving, notify port authorities that we've got Morganas incoming. We're going to make sure they don't get too close, but--
Understood. Good luck, Captain! Ma'am!
Hey, who needs luck? Let's see some hustle!
... Captain. We've got company.
@BATTLE
Pensacola? Feel like tossing a football around?
Oh, Captain, you have no idea.
But I'm supervising a bunch of knuckleheads as they scrub the deck.
The deck's already pretty clean.
Yeah. But I want these guys to know every inch of it, and there's something to be said for bringing their eyes down to six inches from ground-level for an hour or two.

Fields.MenuText: Interesting.
That seems... excessive.
So it's not just that this is the equivalent to a day at the spa for the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: I think you mean "brilliant."
The best missions have more than one achievable objective, Captain.
... But we can spend some time together later. If you like. Especially if you think you need the exercise.

Fields.MenuText: A little exercise might do me good.
Sounds like a plan.
You just had to make it sound threatening, didn't you?

Fields.DialogueText: I know you. You do your best work when threatened.
Good!
Oh, I think I can find ways to make it worth your while.
Don't let up, Cobb! That deck's not going to shine itself!
You want it clean enough to eat off of, because you might have to! In about three hours!
Really?
You have your motivational speeches, I have mine.
... Oh, nuts.
Belay that, Mr. Cobb! I think we're in for a fight! Pensacola, I'll see you on the bridge.
Right.
@BATTLE
Captain? I'm really sorry to bother you - I mean, *really* sorry - but do you have a minute?
I was just on my way to eat. So... sure. What can I do for you, Ensign?
Um... I don't suppose Lieutenant Justice has mentioned Project Echo to you?
That's your study of those Morgana broadcasts?
No, Captain. That didn't really have a name.
Honestly, the idea behind Echo was just... we'd try to build, like, a network of amateur radio operators along the coastline.
And if they started picking up Morgana-style interference they would somehow contact somebody in authority, or even academia, and we could collect data about comings and goings.
Sort of a civilian project to supplement more conventional early warning systems. If that makes any sense.

Fields.MenuText: I hope you're not asking for money.
This your idea, Ensign?
Why don't you skip to why this is urgent?

Fields.DialogueText: No, Captain! Pensacola actually got me a little bit of funding the last time we were in San Diego.
I brainstorm when I'm having trouble sleeping, Captain. Which doesn't actually help with the insomnia, but there you go.
Right.
So, one of the people - one of my friends - who's helping me out with this works for an air freight business, and he just spent a couple of weeks stuck in a Mexican port town called Vallarta.
It's growing - they just got plumbing, I guess - but it's relatively isolated. Especially when the Morgana mist is bad.
And, what, he was picking up radio interference while he was there?
Yes, Captain. And the mist was apparently very thick. He said it actually wasn't safe to fly out when they did, but by then they were more afraid of staying.
I don't know if it was right to report this to you, Captain, but I didn't know who else to tell, and--
I'll look into it, Ensign. Thank you.
Okay. Excellent. I'll just... go back to practicing painting.
Pardon?
Oh, Pensacola wants us to perfect our brush strokes before we touch up any of her real paint. Captain.
... Right. Don't let me stop you.
*ALARM*
I think you just got a reprieve, Ensign.
@BATTLE

I'll remind you, I don't have to ask your permission to respond to a credible threat assessment, and I certainly don't have to sit on my hands on the off chance someone's going to try to strip me of--
A credible threat assessment? To who? To Mexico? That's an American ship you're--
You think it's in American interests to allow a Morgana infestation in the Gulf of California, Admiral? Really?
Captain, if you try to leave San Diego Bay, I will personally mobilize half a dozen destroyers to block your exit and--
Point one - respectfully, you might want to talk to the Secretary of the Navy before you get between me and a potential Morgana infestation.
Point two - do you really want to restrict my movements in a way even Moscow hasn't tried? Is that really publicity the United States needs?
If you want to continue this discussion, you'll be welcome onboard, Admiral - but you'll be coming south with us if you do.
Of all the-- *click*
So. The game is afoot.
Are you picking up any Morgana activity around the bay? This would be a completely different discussion if the place was under imminent assault.
Nope. This is our window.
... Is it just me, or are you happier now than you've been in weeks?
Oh, y'know. I've just been missing doing stupid things.
I don't think we had much of a choice. I've been putting in calls to American businesses with interests on the Mexican west coast, and I'm getting a pretty clear picture of something bad going down.
The League and the U.S. really need to work on intelligence-gathering in the Morgana age. This could've gone on for weeks without a naval response if not for a random ensign and his pen pals.
It's worse than you think. I talked to Commander Keller, and apparently the Mexican government did report the area to the League as a potential area of concern a few days ago.
Then it got tied up some diplomatic argument about relaxing Mexican labor laws for American fruit companies in exchange for expanded investment, and the idea of a recon mission got back-burnered.

Fields.MenuText: I was happier not knowing that.
Above our pay grade, ship's Belle.
You got in touch with Keller, huh?
I'm glad.
That's... just great.
You *do* realize that if he turns out to be untrustworthy I'm going to be insufferable about it.

Fields.DialogueText: The good news is that this means it's officially League business. If anybody's being derelict in their duties here, we've got a strong case it's not us.
I made him promise that if he and his wife have a daughter, they'll name her Pensacola.
I made him promise that if he and his wife have a daughter, they'll name her Pensacola.
No, you wouldn't. We'd make a joint project out of getting revenge. You'd love it.
... You really get me.
Excellent. And stop giving me that knowing look.
Guaranteeing her a life of distinction and adventure.
*I* thought so.
Right. Okay, I need you to listen hard.
You're not the only one.
Yeah, but the Morganas don't make it work.
@BATTLE
I didn't really think you'd be joining us again, Admiral.
I'm not surprised, young lady. Seems to me like you don't always show the best judgment.
I don't think this one thinks of me as a superior officer, though, Captain. And I'm sure *you* don't.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not even American.
I do, Admiral. But I wasn't joking about the Secretary of the Navy.
You might do better talking to her instead of calling her "this one" and not making eye contact.

Fields.DialogueText: That doesn't improve my mood, Captain.
Hrmph.
In my day, if a ship talked back, you hit a pipe with a wrench until it stopped.
Hang on, Admiral. Pensacola? Do we have company?
I think so. Let me listen.
... What's her detection range?
For ships? On a good day, 32 or 33 miles. Sometimes better.
Good for hunting.
Also good as an early warning system.
Yes, I'm very talented. Captain, permission to go set an intercept course? We'll only be deviating seven or eight degrees from our current heading.
Go. I'll meet you on the bridge.
General? Care to join us?
You don't need to convince me that you know how to fight, Captain.
Oh, I know.
Smartass. Fine, let's go.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I've always thought that insulting subordinates amounted to punching down, Admiral. You're better than that.
Keep it civil, Admiral.
*roll eyes*

Fields.DialogueText: Are you giving me an order, Captain?
You want to try that here, you'd have to go through me.
I don't think that's what my combat record suggests, Admiral.
No, Admiral. Just reminding you that simple courtesy makes for smoother sailing.
Plus, you're demonstrably wrong about Pensacola's judgment, and if you press the point you're just going to make yourself look bad.
Hmph.
Come on, come on, come on. Get in before anybody sees you!
Oh, we're sneaking around now? Exciting!

Fields.MenuText: I just don't want the admiral to start grilling me about our fraternization policies.
If Justice finds out the two of us are in one place with free time on our hands, she's going to call a midnight staff meeting.
Ssh! You'll wake up Mom and Dad!

Fields.DialogueText: Goof.
Don't even joke, Captain.
Ugh. Point taken. He'll take me even less seriously if he thinks you're giving me surprise inspections of a Biblical nature.
I feel like there's a Revelations joke in there somewhere, but it's eluding me.
You want a glass of water or anything?
No, thanks. I'm just going to sit. After the day I've had, sitting is my one perfect joy.
Thanks for having me here.
My quarters are your quarters. More or less literally.
Don't tell me that unless you're willing to let me redecorate.
Looking for an excuse to get a paintbrush back in Liu's hands?
Nooooo. He's going to be a great officer one day, but he's *murder* with a brush. Did you know that uneven paint jobs itch?
No. Literally?
Yeah, I feel it in my human body - usually somewhere I can't even reach. The things nobody tells you about being a Belle.
I've got a back-scratcher around here someplace...
Navy-issue?
No, it's a... you're getting that look again.
Yeah. Yeah, I guess I am.
More than one way to scratch an itch, I guess.
Pff. I'll see you on the bridge.
And I'll slip out of here through a bulkhead so nobody suspects we're doing anything sordid.
Yeah, that's not conspicuous at all.
@BATTLE
The Belle's convinced there are more in the area?
Yes, Admiral. And they're still doing a hell of a job keeping us from making contact with the Mexican mainland.
At the rate we're going, I'm afraid you may be able to see first-hand what a coastal infestation looks like.
What are they for? It can't be mineral extraction, can it?
I don't know - we've seen evidence of underwater mining, so I wouldn't rule it out. They may be refueling stations; they may be part of a strategy to take more human prisoners.
At the risk of repeating myself, information-gathering is one of the most important parts of my job right now. There's just too much we don't know about these things.
Sounds to me like what we really need for that is a fleet of spy planes - while our cruisers and battleships do what they were always meant to do. Defend the homeland.
Respectfully, Admiral, we protect the homeland by going out and winning the war, not huddling in a little ball and hoping we don't get kicked.

Fields.MenuText: I wouldn't say no to those spy planes, though.
Thank you, Pensacola. Now think about what it might have sounded like if you'd said it tactfully.
You'll note our Belle has a gift for vivid imagery, Admiral.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, yeah, obviously. I could make room for spy planes.
You say that, but you're grinning.
Heh.
Now put it in Latin and it can be the ship's new slogan.
"Heh." Look at you. Captain Stoic. Admiral, if you-
If I what?
Hang on, Admiral. She's listening.
Pensacola?
Something's going on. I think... I think a destroyer's running away from us, and a bigger group is moving to intercept.
You got this just now?
They're not being subtle.
Right. First things first.
@BATTLE
Y'know, he's still not talking to me.
The admiral?
Yeah. Catch!
Good throw.
I like how you don't even bother to sound impressed. It was a *flawless* throw.
If it had been flawless, the crew would've dropped everything they were doing and started clapping. Do you hear clapping?
Yeah, yeah. Just throw the ball. Not as well as I did, obviously, but--
There. *That* was a flawless throw.
I still don't hear clapping.
That's because the crew knows I'm humble.
Anyway. At least he isn't still calling you "young lady."
I'm pretty sure he's thinking it.

Fields.MenuText: Stop worrying about what you can't control.
No, he's coming around.
If we ever make it to Puerto Vallarta we can accidentally leave him there.

Fields.DialogueText: I have yet to encounter anything I can't control, Captain. Haven't you been paying attention?
I think maybe you've been out in the sun too long.
Don't tempt me.
Yeah, yeah. Just throw the ball.
Actually... this might not be the time.
Is the situation changing?
Sort of. Some of the ships that have hovering around just at the edge of my range are coming together. Ahead of us.
You think they're trying to slow us down?
I think they're trying to kill us - but, failing that, they're aiming for slow.
I don't know what they're doing down here, but I'm liking it less and less. I wonder if it's another grab for the Panama Canal.
One fight at a time, Captain.
@BATTLE
I'd swear it's a Vanity, Captain. I can hear her engines from here and they sound like saber-tooth tigers purring.
So they really *are* throwing the big guns at us now. Interesting.
That's one word for it.
Admiral?
This is what happened with the Marshall Islands.
You went out of your way to "investigate," without means of contacting your allies, and the enemy took advantage of your exposure and tried to bring you down with sheer numbers.
Pensacola's at risk, there's no sign of a significant strategic gain, and we're just thundering forward in the hopes that something will turn up that'll make it all worthwhile.
In the case of the Marshall Islands, that "something" was being called "the liberation of Majuro" in the press by the time we left San Diego.
And Pensacola and I agree that we're not just attracting opportunistic fire - we're breaking through Morgana defenses.

Fields.MenuText: Aren't you curious about what they're trying to defend?
Seeking out, studying, and eliminating unusual Morgana assets is a big part of my mandate.
We're literally breaking through those defenses *right now.*

Fields.DialogueText: Sure. If I were in San Diego I'd argue for sending a plane down to Vallarta to check it all out.
If you were in San Diego, you probably wouldn't know there was anything to investigate. We really need to ramp up American intelligence sharing with-
Don't even start, Captain.
You haven't proven to me that it's worth jeopardizing my ships to do it.
I'm sorry. *Your* ships?
In that it's my job to keep you from being wasted, yep. Deal with it.
Right. Pensacola - how close are we to that Vanity?
In a few minutes I think you'll see for yourself.
@BATTLE
Admiral, I promise you, nobody is more invested in Pensacola's well-being and continued service than I am. She can handle everything they're throwing at her.
It's a team sport, Captain.
Hmph.
I'm positive that's Puerto Vallarta out there, Captain.
I can't see a thing. I can't *hear* a thing. Even in the mist, in broad daylight that's... not normal.
I've climbed as high as I can go and I've squinted - and you know what my eyes are like.
The port's taken a lot of damage. It may have been evacuated.
If the atmosphere is toxic, visibility is miserable, and radio jammed, evacuation wouldn't have been easy.
We need to clear out the local Morganas, thin the mist, and get somebody on land to find out what's going on.
For what it's worth, I concur.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you, Admiral.
Glad to hear it, Admiral.
I wonder if one of us is doing something wrong.

Fields.DialogueText: Joke later, Captain.
You think it's going to be bad out there?

Fields.MenuText: We won't know until we see.
Yeah. Yeah, I'm afraid so.
You didn't really get to see what they did back in the Marshall Islands, did you?

Fields.DialogueText: Right.
No. We were in and out too quickly.
It wasn't pretty there, either.
Hang on. Captain?
Found the enemy?
Or they found us.
Unlucky them.
@BATTLE
No harbormaster. Nobody to help us dock. It's really unsettling.
I wouldn't *want* to dock with Morganas active in the area and land defenses... I guess "stripped" is the word.
I hope Liu's okay out there. I know we had to send a team to see what's going on, but....

Fields.MenuText: He will be.
He will be if he's smart about it.
He does speak Spanish, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah.
How are *you* holding up, Captain? This hasn't exactly turned out to be a pleasure cruise.

Fields.MenuText: They never are.
I'd rather be here with you than on some sleek French destroyer, I'll tell you that.
You know me. I'm just repressing everything until the war's over.

Fields.DialogueText: You?
I'm okay. At least we're doing something, y'know? I had visions of being stuck in San Diego Bay waiting for the admiral to find a way to get you dragged off in chains.
In chains?
I... have to admit, I'm not at my most rational when I think about you leaving me.
Hsst!
What? Morganas?
Yeah. They're trying a sub on us this time, I think.
Great.
@BATTLE
Flatterer.

Fields.MenuText: Just wanted to be sure it wasn't a weird bondage fantasy.
I feel the same way, for what it's worth.
It's not going to happen.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, see, now I've got something entirely new to--
The people still there don't know what's going on, Captain, Admiral, but they're absolutely sure that the Morganas were taking prisoners as well as steel.
There's some project going on further down the coast - the Morganas are drilling into the cliffs at a place called La Quebrada, and the Mexican Army's just in no position to deal with it. The mist--
We get it, Ensign.
And the prisoners? They're... what, hostages? Slave labor?
If they're lucky. Morganas aren't above experimentation.
... This is why we need you at home. This could be California. This could be Florida. I don't know why you don't see that.
Admiral, I don't think this is--
I'm talking to Pensacola, Captain.
Well, that's a pleasant change.
I'm not looking for lip, young lady. I'm being serious. I respect your loyalty to your captain, but you have to see how vulnerable we are at home. And how vulnerable you are out here!
Can you really tell me you think it's in America's best interests to have you - to have all our fleets - scattered around and deployed randomly just to serve one officer's curiosity?
Do you really care what my answer is? I don't mean that disrespectfully - I'm genuinely curious. Because you have to know I'm going to say I *do* believe it's in America's best interests.
Um. Captain, if I'm finished here--
Hang on. You haven't said much about the condition of Vallarta itself.
It's not great, Captain. People have tried to get further away from the sea, but the community's fairly isolated; there aren't really any major roads to anywhere else.
There was a garrison by the mouth of the river, but the Morganas seem to have shelled it all to hell.
The surviving soldiers are billeting in civilian homes, but I don't think they have the weaponry to do much good if the Morganas stick around.
They're cut off from fishing, medical supplies are running low - it's not good.

Fields.MenuText: Right. We'll share what supplies we can.
The Mexican government has to know something's going on by now.
The best thing we can do for them is obliterate the Morgana infestation at La Quebrada.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, for God's sake!
I hope so, Captain.
It's not like we're emptying the penicillin drawer, Admiral.
Agreed.
But, Captain... I think we have a more immediate problem.
Yeah, I suppose it's about time. Thank you, Ensign. You'd better get to where you need to be.
Aye-aye!
@BATTLE
We're almost at La Quebrada. It really wasn't a long trip.
And, whatever the Morganas are up to, they mean to defend it.  There's an assault group coming from deeper in the Pacific; that's what I just picked up on.
With your permission, I'd like to change course to intercept. Hopefully we can clear them out before reinforcements can come in from further south.
Listen, when I got my hands on you, before I knew you, I just thought you were my ticket to getting missions that mattered.
Hello, you.
Hello to you too. And don't worry - nobody saw me make my way here. No one will know of our... secret assignations.
You're enjoying that too much.
What, the skulking around? Or the teasing you for telling me to skulk around?

Fields.MenuText: Teasing me. Definitely the teasing me.
Actually, I like the teasing part.
Probably both.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, gosh. I'll try to do a better job of it in the future.
I know.
I think you'll find that I'm enjoying them both exactly the proper amount.
So. What're you up to? Did I interrupt anything interesting?
No. I was just thinking.
... The admiral got in your head?
Mm. That thing he said the other day about... I don't know, isolating you because of "one officer's curiosity." You know that's been on my mind since the days of the Majuro trap.
I don't want relief.
Would you tell me if you did?
I wouldn't have to. You're right here with me.
Well, yes. Always.
I didn't expect that I'd also get someone who made my job feel less lonely.
I don't know about those Japanese girls who think we're all really goddesses - I mean, I don't feel like a goddess.
But one thing they tend to express better than the rest of us is that our crews need specific things from us. They can't think we're vulnerable, or afraid, or confused.
We can't really be in command, but we have to be symbols of command. We have to... I don't know.
Keep going.
... Even with somebody like Justice, who I really do think of as a friend, I have a job that comes first. I can tease her, but I have to inspire her too.
I get it.
I know you do.
... I think, if you weren't under my command, I might hug you now.
Well, that's what secret assignations are for, goofus.
That's "Captain Goofus" to you.
Yeah, you can expect that to come back to haunt you.
Even as I said it, I knew it was a mistake.
Yeah, that... um.
Oh, dammit. Them again?
Yeah. And it's a good reminder I didn't just come here to be flirted with.
Right. Do it. I'll meet you on the bridge in a few minutes.
Okay.
But, just because the subject has finally been introduced, you didn't *not* come here to be flirted with, right?
My only regret is that it's too soon to play the Captain Goofus card.
That wasn't a no!
@BATTLE
And we *are* vulnerable out here, and there's really no hope of relief.
Flatterer.
Lieutenant, I want to be sure we're ready for rescuees - probably in states of severe distress.
The Morganas we're about to encounter may have captured civilians onboard, and there's reason to believe some will be at their... project location as well.
Pensacola's had us drilling search and rescue non-stop for days, Captain. We're--
*Some* of you insisted on sleeping so you wouldn't die. So much drama.
Yes, ma'am. We're ready, Captain. And we've got plans to set up relief stations on the deck as well, depending on... um... how much deck is left not on fire when the shooting stops.

Fields.MenuText: Good work, Lieutenant.
I can't stress enough how important speed could be in this, Lieutenant.
Right. Is there anything else you need from me to make this work?

Fields.DialogueText: Good wishes?
Officially given.
I know, Captain. We're as ready as we can be.
Thank you, Captain.
I know it's going to be even harder for doing this at night, but I don't want to give Morgana reinforcements any time to sneak up and box us in.
Pensacola says there's one battleship group hovering in proximity to the cliffs. We clear it out, we rescue everyone we can find, and then we blow the hell out of the cliffside operation.
Hopefully research teams can be flown in after to piece together what these things are up to.
Pensacola, anything to add?
You all know your jobs, and nobody has permission to get killed.
That sums it up nicely. Let's get this done, people.
@BATTLE
Have a seat, Admiral. There's beer if you want it - warm, I'm afraid.
I can live with warm. Thank you, Captain.
None for me. I'm driving.
So, what's this all about, Captain? Are you going to try to talk me out of getting Pensacola reassigned?
Admiral, I think we both know I don't have to. If you had a chance at all, it was when we'd just gotten back from Majuro and nobody really knew how successful we'd been.
Instead of rallying your forces, you ran off with us. I guarantee, by the time we can contact American authorities, the window for arguing Pensacola isn't effective under my command will have closed.
If you invited me here to gloat, I appreciate the booze.

Fields.MenuText: All part of the service.
I'll keep the gloating to a minimum.
You're not naive, Admiral. You knew when you came onboard what it meant.

Fields.DialogueText: Hm.
You're right, obviously. I was having no traction removing you back in San Diego. Don't get me wrong - there are men in high places who like you a lot less than I do.
But nobody wants to cross you openly until they're sure they can take you down.
I don't suppose you'd care to share any names.
Stop. We're not going to put him on the spot.
So why *am* I here?
We want to work with you, you idiot!
Listen, your arguments about starving the Morganas out with a strong defense may not account for everything they're up to - but it's not like we think you're wrong, either.
I've had people trying to figure out ways to improve our capacity to detect these b-words from distance, and--
"B-words?"
I'm avoiding needless vulgarity, Captain. I'm not a barbarian.
Duly noted.
The point is, Admiral, we know you're a smart son of a b-word, and we know we need to find a way to work with you.
Even if you don't agree with my mandate, we're all willing to fight and die to keep California and the U.S. safe. There have to be ideas we can share and strategies we can agree on.
We're hoping you've spent enough time with us now to see we're sincere. And we're good at what we do.
... Are you both done?
Don't bother. When I was courting the woman who would one day be my wife, if her father had ever once caught me looking at her the way you look at Pensacola...
Well, honestly, it would've ended in a heated conversation over a shotgun.
Listen, one of the strangest things the U.S. Navy has figured out since the Belle... situation... began is that crews are remarkably accepting of captain-Belle entanglements.
The kids like it when mommy and daddy are together, so to speak.
Not quite.
Admiral, Belles are military. We respect the chain of command. *I* respect the chain of command.
If the Captain has to serve on another ship someday, nobody here is going to defy orders to stop it from happening.
But I want you to know that I'm not human. And I feel things you don't. And I chose the commanding officer that I know my crew needs.
That *I* need.
If you ever try to change that again, I would appreciate the courtesy of looking me in the eye and trying to explain why.
... That's fair.
Listen, Captain, on top of everything that young lady just said, my daughters would tear me a new one for getting in the way of young love without being man enough to admit it.
... Pardon?
Now, would you give me a moment alone with the Captain here, please?
I... yes, Admiral. But shout if you need me.
... Noted.
But they don't like ambiguity, Captain, and I don't think they have much respect for someone who doesn't treat their Belle right. You get my meaning?
I think so, Admiral.
Good. Very good.
You know, for warm beer, this isn't bad.
Stations, everyone - let's give the Admiral a show!
@BATTLE
You spent a lot of time on the radio this morning.
It's the best connection we've had with Mexican authorities since we came south. They were... understandably curious about what we've been up to and why we had to shell the cliffs.
You better. It wouldn't be the same without you.
Are you in trouble again?
Am *I* in trouble? Hey, if they seized the ship, you'd be the one flying Mexican colors.
I'd be okay. My Spanish is excellent.
Yeah, yeah. And, no, I'm not in trouble. They're sending somebody out to collect our rescued prisoners - and they'll be working with Americans who're coming to examine the Morgana wreckage.
Good.
It could've been better. Some of our rescuees are in pretty rough shape.
True. But if we hadn't been here, I think a lot of them would be dead. I get the sense the Morganas forgot people need food and water.
*sigh*
Can I ask you something?
Shoot.
That business about the admiral's window for separating us closing when he joined us on the trip out of San Diego. Were you serious?
Yeah. I don't think he had much hope of splitting us up in the first place, but... well, if he had, he didn't play his cards right.
So, was this a plan? All of it? Getting him angry over the radio, daring him to come onboard, spiriting him away?

Fields.MenuText: Honestly? No. I was really just mouthing off back then.
I'll never tell.
Less a plan, more an improvisation that paid off.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. I wouldn't want you to start thinking you're clever or anything.
Jerk.
The best kind of improvisation, I guess.
Y'know... for all the running around we've done over the last couple of months, and for all the tension we've had about the admiral's plans to take you away from me-
Or vice-versa.
Or vice-versa. Anyway, for all that, I don't think I've ever taken the time to thank you for choosing me to be your captain.
... I'll see you on the bridge.
No, you haven't. And I'd say it's long overdue.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah?
In fairness, you haven't thanked me for accepting the job, either.
And, see, this is why I haven't. You're enjoying it too much.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, maybe we should find a way to thank each other at the same time.
Oh, yeah.
Lucky for you you're cute enough to get away with lines like that.
Listen. The other day... I mean, I hate to say it, but the admiral may have had a point.
So, yeah, what he said about us. And about ambiguity being a bad idea. And about me looking at you in a way that might send your father to get a shotgun.
I'm pretty sure my father is the New York Navy Yard.
It would be a pretty big shotgun, yeah.
Ha!
You know, Captain, if you wanted to kiss me, you... you could...
Oh, no. Please no. Please tell me they're not--
Morganas inbound.
Now? Right this minute NOW?
Sorry.
But maybe we can return to the topic of kissing later on...
If you mean something he said after I left, you should probably bring me up to speed, Captain.
Uh-huh. Given that nobody explicitly ordered you not to listen in...
Heh.
